description:
The verb is from Middle English crien (13th century), from Old French crier (â€œto announce publicly, proclaim, scream, shoutâ€) (whence Medieval Latin crÄ«dÅ (â€œto cry out, shout, publish, proclaimâ€)).
The noun is from Middle English crie, from Old French cri, crÃ¯ee.

The origin of the Old French (and Middle Latin) word is uncertain, if Germanic, it is from Frankish *krÄ«tan (â€œto cry, cry out, publishâ€), from Proto-Germanic *krÄ«tanÄ… (â€œto cry out, shoutâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *greyd- (â€œto shoutâ€). Cognate with Saterland Frisian kriete (â€œto cryâ€), Dutch krijten (â€œto cryâ€) and krijsen (â€œto shriekâ€), German Low German krieten (â€œto cry, call out, shriekâ€), German kreiÃŸen (â€œto cry loudly, wail, groanâ€), Gothic ğŒºğ‚ğŒ´ğŒ¹ğ„ğŒ°ğŒ½ (kreitan, â€œto cry, scream, call outâ€), further Indo-European cognates: Latin gingrÄ«tus (â€œthe cackling of geeseâ€), Middle Irish grith (â€œa cryâ€), Welsh gryd (â€œa screamâ€), Persian Ú¯Ø±ÛŒÙ‡â€ (gerye, â€œto cryâ€), Sanskrit à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨ (krandana, â€œcry, lamentationâ€).

An alternate etymology connects the Medieval Latin word to  quiritÅ (â€œto wail, shriekâ€). This is itself of uncertain origin, perhaps from  Latin queror (â€œto complainâ€) through the form, though the phonetic and semantic developments are difficult to trace; alternatively,  a variant of quirritare (â€œto squeal like a pigâ€), from *quis, an onomatopoeic rendition of squeaking. An ancient folk etymology understood it as  "to call for the help of the Quirites," the Roman constabulary.

entries.meaning: A shedding of tears; the act of crying.
examples: After we broke up, I retreated to my room for a good cry.
I heard a cry from afar.

[â€¦]  Before the gates there sat / On either side a formidable shape; / The one seemâ€™d woman to the waste, and fair, / But ended foul in many a scaly fold / Voluminous and vast, a serpent armâ€™d / With mortal sting: about her middle round / A cry of hell-hounds never ceasing barkâ€™d / With wide Cerberean mouths full loud and rung / A hideous peal; yet, when they list,would creep, / If ought disturb'd their noise, into her womb, / and kennel there, yet there still barkâ€™d and howlâ€™d, / Within unseen.  [â€¦]

entries.meaning: (by extension, obsolete, derogatory) A pack or company of people.
(of an animal) A typical sound made by the species in question.
examples: "Woof" is the cry of a dog, while "neigh" is the cry of a horse.

verbs.description: cry (third-person singular simple present cries, present participle crying, simple past and past participle cried)

examples: That sad movie always makes me cry.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To utter loudly; to call out; to declare publicly.
(intransitive) To utter inarticulate sounds, as animals do.
(transitive) To cause to do something, or bring to some state, by crying or weeping.
examples: Tonight Iâ€™ll cry myself to sleep.

entries.meaning: To make oral and public proclamation of; to notify or advertise by outcry, especially things lost or found, goods to be sold, auctioned, etc.
Hence, to publish the banns of, as for marriage.
examples: I should not be surprised if they were cried in church next Sabbath.
